questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for joint pain following the acute onset of a diffuse, pruritic rash for the past 24 hours. A week ago, he was diagnosed with pharyngitis after returning home from summer camp and is currently taking antibiotics. There is no family history of serious illness. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema, generalized lymphadenopathy, and well-circumscribed, erythematous, confluent skin lesions of variable sizes up to several centimeters in width over his entire body. There is pain on passive movement of wrists and ankle joints bilaterally. Urine dipstick shows 1+ proteinuria. There is no hematuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching medication to doxycycline would be appropriate if this patient had Lyme disease, which may be suspected given his recent camping experience. However, unlike this patient, the skin rash in patients with early Lyme presents as a localized (single) circular, slowly expanding, erythematous ring around the bite site with central clearing.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of a serum sickness-like reaction (SSLR), a condition often caused by medications such as antibiotics and anticonvulsants. It can also occur after streptococcal infections, viral infections, and certain vaccines. It is believed that drug metabolites serve as haptens that bind covalently to serum proteins (e.g., albumin), which can activate the immune system. If a particular medication can be identified as the causative agent, it should be discontinued or replaced.

SSLR is a clinical diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

While corticosteroids, such as prednisone, may help reduce the inflammatory response of SSLR, another step is more important to manage the underlying cause at this time. Corticosteroids should be considered as first-line treatment in patients with severe Still disease, nephrotic syndrome, or anaphylaxis, among others. Although this patient has features of each of these conditions (Still disease: arthritis, skin rash; nephrotic syndrome: proteinuria, periorbital edema; anaphylaxis: skin rash; periorbital edema), the constellation of skin rash, polyarticular arthritis, fever, periorbital edema, and generalized lymphadenopathy, cannot be explained by any of these diseases alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergy testing is indicated in individuals with a history of allergic reactions, both chronic (e.g., food allergies, hay fever) and acute (e.g., drug reactions), to detect the causative allergen. In individuals with an SSLR, allergy testing can be considered but is usually not indicated, as a reliable diagnosis can be established clinically.

E) INCORRECT:

EBV serology is not indicated for SSLR but can be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected infectious mononucleosis (IM). While the administration of an aminopenicillin (e.g., amoxicillin or ampicillin) in IM can lead to the development of a generalized rash, it is typically maculopapular and nonpruritic. Furthermore, this etiology is unlikely in a patient without additional characteristic symptoms of an IM (e.g., tonsillitis with typical white deposits, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly).
Image Description:

Pharynx and tonsils in a patient with infectious mononucleosis

The tonsils are massively hypertrophied, touching at the midline (known as “kissing tonsils”), and covered with gray-white exudate. The visible parts of the pharynx are erythematous.

F) INCORRECT:

Although ibuprofen should be considered to address the patient's fever and joint pain, another step is more important to manage the underlying cause of SSLR at this time. NSAIDs like ibuprofen are first-line therapy for Still disease, which also presents with joint pain and a skin rash. However, the condition would also cause swollen joints, early morning stiffness, and limited joint movement, none of which is present in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Although diphenhydramine would relieve the pruritus and skin rash of SSLR, another step is more important to manage the underlying cause at this time. Diphenhydramine would be indicated for suspected anaphylaxis, which would cause an acute, diffuse, pruritic rash and periorbital edema. However, a reaction would not last 24 hours and would likely also involve other common features such as sneezing, chest tightness, dyspnea, wheezing, and possible cardiovascular compromise (circulatory failure, distributive shock).
questions.hint: This patient has a fever, pruritic rash, facial edema, polyarthralgia, lymphadenopathy, and mild proteinuria. These symptoms started shortly after he began taking a new medication, which suggests a serum sickness-like reaction (SSLR).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, itchy rash, and generalized joint pain. The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and then spread to her trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, she was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on amoxicillin. She has no history of adverse drug reactions and immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over her entire body. One of the lesions in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing and the patient's mother reports that it has been present for over 24 hours. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Serum sickness-like reaction (SSLR) resembles true serum sickness. Both diseases manifest with fever, rash (urticaria or purpura), and arthralgia, which usually occur 1–2 weeks after an inciting agent (usually an antibiotic) is initiated. True serum sickness disease is classically a type III hypersensitivity reaction (with metabolites acting as haptens on normal cells), while SSLR is much more common than serum sickness and of unclear etiology. Symptoms of true serum sickness are typically more severe (e.g., high-grade fever), with an acute or subacute onset, while symptoms of SSLR are usually less severe (e.g., low-grade fever), with a more insidious onset.

B) INCORRECT:

Anaphylactic reactions can develop in response to amoxicillin and manifest with an urticarial rash and facial swelling. However, anaphylaxis manifests immediately following administration of the drug with a variable combination of skin and mucosal involvement (swelling of the tongue or uvula), respiratory compromise, hypotension, and gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, vomiting), which, with the exception of a rash, are not seen in this patient. Finally, anaphylaxis occurs within minutes to hours of exposure to the offending agent, while it has been a week since this patient started antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) manifests with a rash, fever, and arthralgia within 4–28 days of exposure to an offending agent like amoxicillin. However, the rash seen in SJS involves necrosis and detachment of the epidermis, which causes erythema, pain, and blistering, while urticaria is seen here. Moreover, in 90% of patients with SJS, mucous membrane involvement (e.g., stomatitis, conjunctivitis, urethritis, painful ulcers) occurs, whereas it is not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris also manifests with a rash and can be exacerbated by certain drugs, including amoxicillin. However, pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by the spontaneous appearance of painful, flaccid, intraepidermal blisters, which can rupture and become confluent (erosions and crusts). These ruptured blisters re-epithelialize with hyperpigmentation, but urticaria is usually not seen. Moreover, pemphigus vulgaris lesions typically first appear on the oral mucosa and then on body parts exposed to pressure (e.g., intertriginous areas), not the antecubital and popliteal fossae. Moreover, the peak incidence of pemphigus vulgaris is 40–60 years of age, and manifestation in childhood is extremely rare. Finally, amoxicillin is very rarely responsible for exacerbations in pemphigus vulgaris; drugs that more commonly exacerbate pemphigus vulgaris include ACE inhibitors, penicillamine, phenobarbital, and penicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that also causes rash, fever, and facial edema. However, DRESS typically occurs 2–8 weeks after exposure to the offending agent, while only a week has passed in this case. Furthermore, the antibiotic agents that cause DRESS are most commonly sulfonamides, minocycline, and vancomycin; it is only rarely caused by amoxicillin.

F) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme (EM) can occur secondary to drugs, including amoxicillin, and manifests with an itchy rash, low-grade fever, and arthralgia. However, the target lesions of EM have a dark center rather than central clearing and classically appear on the back of the hands and top of the feet first rather than the antecubital and popliteal fossae. Moreover, mucous membrane involvement (e.g., painful ulcers), which is often seen in EM, is not seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis also manifests with an urticarial rash and arthralgia following upper respiratory infection or treatment with certain antibiotics. However, the rash in IgA vasculitis takes the form of raised, erythematous macules that coalesce into palpable purpura (non-blanching skin lesions). Additionally, the rash usually appears first on areas of pressure or constraint (e.g., from socks or clothing), which classically include the lower extremities and buttocks, not the antecubital and popliteal fossae. Finally, IgA vasculitis is very rarely caused by amoxicillin.
questions.hint: This patient's reaction to amoxicillin (first-line therapy for acute sinusitis) can also occur secondary to hepatitis B or streptococcal infections.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of nausea, abdominal discomfort, and yellow discoloration of the eyes. Six weeks ago, he had an episode of fever, joint pain, swollen lymph nodes, and an itchy rash on his trunk and extremities that persisted for 1 to 2 days. He returned from a backpacking trip to Colombia two months ago. His temperature is 39°C (101.8°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Infection with which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B is associated with a serum sickness-like reaction, which typically occurs during the prodromal period of the infection 1-2 weeks after antigen exposure and is thought to be mediated by immune complex formation. Symptoms of serum sickness-like reaction usually resolve within a few weeks, but symptoms from acute HBV infection may persist for longer, as seen in this patient. Other causes of serum sickness-like reaction include antibiotics (cefaclor, penicillin), streptococcal infection, and vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) infection is a common cause of traveler's diarrhea that can cause nausea, abdominal cramping, and fever, similar to the symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's history of rash and current jaundice would not be explained by ETEC. Furthermore, he is lacking the acute, watery diarrhea that is characteristic of ETEC infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne pathogen that causes Lyme disease. Patients with Lyme disease may present with fever, lymphadenopathy, transient arthritis, and jaundice. However, Lyme disease would typically present with erythema migrans, not an itchy rash involving the trunk and extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis (IM), which can manifest with fever, nausea, arthralgias, abdominal discomfort, jaundice, and lymphadenopathy. Although uncommon, a maculopapular rash can also occur in patients with IM. This patient, however, does not have other characteristic features of IM, such as pharyngitis, tonsillitis, and splenomegaly. Additionally, this patient had a prodromal syndrome about 6 weeks before his current symptoms, which does not occur in IM.

E) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacterium that classically causes bloody diarrhea but can also cause reactive arthritis, which may present similarly to this patient. However, it is not known to cause liver pathology and this patient is missing the classic symptoms of conjunctivitis and urethritis typically seen in reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient's current condition (jaundice, nausea) suggest liver pathology, and his medical history suggests a serum sickness-like reaction (fever, arthritis, itchy rash).

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-hour history of fever, an itchy rash, and generalized body aches. Ten days ago, he received treatment in the emergency department for a snake bite. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 120/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple well-demarcated, raised, erythematous plaques over the trunk. There is tenderness to palpation and decreased range of motion of the metacarpophalangeal and wrist joints bilaterally. Urine dipstick shows 2+ protein. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Keratinocyte necrosis on skin biopsy is associated with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), a condition that can cause fever, dermatologic manifestations, myalgia, and polyarthritis within days to weeks after exposure to an inciting drug. However, the characteristic dermatologic manifestations of SJS are widespread blisters and erosions of the skin and mucosal surfaces, not truncal urticaria. This patient likely has serum sickness, which is not associated with keratinocyte necrosis on skin biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers indicate recent streptococcal infection. Complications of streptococcal pharyngitis include rheumatic fever and scarlet fever. Rheumatic fever is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that can cause fever, dermatologic manifestations, and polyarthritis. Scarlet fever can cause fever, dermatologic manifestations, and myalgia. However, the characteristic dermatologic manifestations of rheumatic fever are subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum, and the characteristic dermatologic manifestations of scarlet fever are a sandpaper-like, erythematous rash and a strawberry tongue. Neither of these conditions causes an urticarial rash or proteinuria. This patient likely has serum sickness, which is not associated with positive ASO titers.

C) INCORRECT:

IgG antibodies against hemidesmosomes develop in patients with bullous pemphigoid, a type II hypersensitivity reaction that can manifest with a prodromal urticarial rash. However, this condition does not cause fever, myalgia, polyarthritis, or proteinuria. This patient likely has serum sickness, which is not associated with a positive ELISA for anti-hemidesmosome antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Tryptase is released upon mast cell degranulation. Increased serum tryptase concentrations are associated with type I hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., acute anaphylaxis), which can cause fever and an urticarial rash within minutes to hours after exposure to an allergen. These reactions do not typically cause myalgia, polyarthritis, or proteinuria. In addition, though this patient has a potential allergen exposure from treatment of a snake bite, this exposure occurred 10 days ago. This patient likely has serum sickness, which is not associated with an increased serum tryptase concentration.

E) CORRECT:

Antibody-antigen complexes form after exposure to nonhuman protein antigens (e.g., venom anti-toxins, microbial anti-toxins). If these complexes are inadequately cleared by the mononuclear phagocyte system, they can deposit in tissues and cause serum sickness due to the resulting inflammatory response. This response includes complement system activation and consumption, which results in a decreased serum complement concentration.

Additional manifestations of serum sickness include headache, blurry vision, edema, lymphadenopathy, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, diarrhea), glomerulonephritis, and vasculitis.
Image Description:

Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) are formed in the circulation and get deposited in tissues, preferably within the vascular endothelium, certain organs (e.g., kidney, lung), and the serosal membranes (e.g., synovium, pleura, pericardium).

The deposited immune complexes activate the complement cascade, resulting in chemotaxis (recruitment of neutrophils). The antigen-bound IgG bind to the Fc receptors (FcR) on the surface of neutrophils that then release lysosomal enzymes, which damage the local tissues.

The site of immune complex deposition determines the clinical features of a type III hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., Arthus reaction, vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, synovitis, pneumonitis).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has serum sickness after receiving anti-snake venom. This condition is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that typically manifests with fever, an urticarial rash, myalgia, polyarthritis, and proteinuria 1–2 weeks after exposure to nonhuman protein antigens.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being bitten in the leg by a rattlesnake while hiking. Soon after arriving, he begins developing systemic symptoms, and snake antivenom is administered. His symptoms improve, and he is discharged home. Twelve days later, he starts experiencing intermittent fevers to 38.1°C, a serpiginous maculopapular eruption on his legs, and mild joint pain in his hands.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin E-mediated allergy to snake antivenom

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain drugs may cause hypersensitivity vasculitis reactions, but this type of reaction has not been associated with administration of snake antivenom.

B) INCORRECT:

Type I (immunoglobulin E-mediated) hypersensitivity reactions require previous sensitization to a food, drug, or heterologous protein, and they are generally immediate in nature. The immunoglobulin E-mediated activation of mast cells results in a vasoactive response, with clinical manifestations such as anaphylaxis, bronchospasm, and hives.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyrogenic reactions to antivenom are caused by pyrogen contamination during manufacture and may include chills, rigors, fever, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, and hypotension secondary to vasodilation. Bacterial lipopolysaccharides are the most common pyrogens in antivenoms. Reactions typically occur within the first hour after antivenom administration.

D) INCORRECT:

Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reactions are T-cell mediated and do not manifest with fever or joint pain.

E) CORRECT:

The timing of symptom onset and the nature of the symptoms in this case are crucial in determining if the patient is experiencing a type III hypersensitivity reaction to the previously administered heterologous protein.

Type III (serum-sickness) hypersensitivity reactions typically appear 7 to 14 days after a patient receives heterologous nonhuman serum proteins. The formation of immune complexes, which deposit in vessels or tissue and trigger complement activation, results in serpiginous maculopapular eruptions, fever, and joint pain, as this patient is experiencing.

Key learning point: The length of time between the administration of a heterologous protein snake antivenom and the development of a serum-sickness hypersensitivity reaction is typically 1 to 2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man, who was once an avid hunter, received a heart transplant 5 years ago for a cardiomyopathy. He received a dose of rabbit antithymocyte globulin (ATG) at the time of transplantation and then again 2 years later for treatment of rejection. Recently, he developed shortness of breath, and his cardiac function was found to be markedly reduced. He was thought to be having another rejection episode and was again treated with rabbit ATG as well as with glucocorticoids. Ten days after receiving the ATG, the patient developed a fever, a rash (figure), and arthralgias of the knees, wrists, ankles, and shoulders.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of transplant rejection include fatigue, shortness of breath, edema, and low-grade fever. Arthralgias and morbilliform rashes are not characteristic of rejection reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is rare in adults. It occurs after pharyngitis caused by group A Streptococcus. The typical rash of rheumatic fever is erythema marginatum, not a morbilliform rash.

C) CORRECT:

Type III hypersensitivity reactions, also known as serum sickness reactions, can cause fever, joint pain, and rash that start 7 to 10 days after exposure to heterologous nonhuman serum proteins. These reactions are caused by the formation of immune complexes that consist of the heterologous protein and protein-specific immunoglobulins. There are currently no methods to predict who will develop serum sickness. Risk factors in this patient include prior exposure to the antigen through previous exposure to rabbit antithymocyte globulin as well as probable exposure to rabbits while hunting.

Key learning point: The development of joint pain, rash, and fever 7 to 10 days after treatment with rabbit antithymocyte globulin in someone who had previously received this agent is most consistent with the diagnosis of serum sickness (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

D) INCORRECT:

The skin manifestations of bacterial endocarditis are typically petechiae and splinter hemorrhages, not a morbilliform rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions typically occur 24 to 48 hours after administration of the offending agent, and the clinical features range from mild contact dermatitis to severe exfoliative dermatitis. Although fever can occur with severe reactions, a morbilliform eruption is not a typical feature of any of them.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, joint pain, and a rash that developed over the past 2 days. He was treated with crotaline antivenom (CroFab) 2 weeks ago for a rattlesnake bite. Physical examination shows a temperature of 101.5°F (38.6°C), symmetric arthritis of his wrists and ankles, and an urticarial rash on his trunk and extremities. His neck is supple and neurological examination is normal. Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are unremarkable. Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain blood cultures and start empiric antibiotics
Order rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies
Perform lumbar puncture and CSF analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine and high-dose corticosteroids are indicated for anaphylaxis, a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs within minutes to hours of exposure. This patient has a delayed reaction occurring weeks after exposure and does not require emergency anaphylaxis treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction that typically occurs 1–3 weeks after antivenom administration. The classic triad includes fever, arthralgias, and rash (urticarial or purpuric). Treatment involves systemic corticosteroids, H1 blockers, and NSAIDs for symptomatic relief. The condition is self-limited once the offending antigen is cleared.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures and antibiotics would be appropriate for suspected septic arthritis or bacteremia. However, the symmetric joint involvement, timing relative to antivenom administration, and characteristic rash pattern make serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, the most likely diagnosis rather than infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies are used to evaluate for rheumatoid arthritis. While serum sickness can mimic inflammatory arthritis, the acute onset following antivenom administration and associated rash make serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, more likely than autoimmune arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture and CSF analysis would be indicated for suspected meningitis if the patient had signs of meningeal irritation or altered mental status. This patient's presentation with fever, rash, and arthritis following recent antivenom exposure is consistent with serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, rather than central nervous system infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 10 days after completing a 3-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. She complains of fever, generalized joint pain, and a skin rash that developed over the past 3 days. Vital signs show temperature 101.2°F (38.4°C), blood pressure 130/85 mmHg, heart rate 95 bpm, and respirations 18/min. Physical examination reveals an urticarial rash on her trunk and extremities, bilateral wrist and ankle tenderness without effusion, and mild cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically involves bullae, skin necrosis, and mucosal involvement, which are not present in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever requires preceding streptococcal infection and typically presents with migratory large joint arthritis, carditis, and other specific criteria. The temporal relationship to antibiotic administration and the urticarial rash pattern do not support this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with the classic triad of serum sickness: fever, rash (urticarial), and arthralgias occurring 1–3 weeks after exposure to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Serum sickness is a type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition following exposure to medications such as antibiotics. The timing, clinical presentation, and recent antibiotic exposure make this the most likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced lupus erythematosus typically manifests ≥ 1 month after medication initiation and is characterized by the presence of antihistone antibodies and positive ANAs. While trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is a known trigger for drug-induced lupus, the 10-day onset in this case is too short, and the urticarial rash pattern is more consistent with an immune complex-mediated reaction rather than the typical manifestations of drug-induced lupus.

E) INCORRECT:

Post-infectious arthritis typically occurs after bacterial infections and presents with asymmetric joint inflammation, often with joint effusions. The urticarial rash, fever pattern, and temporal relationship to antibiotic administration are not characteristic of post-infectious arthritis.
